title: Impaired, Distracted & Drowsy Driving
objectives: Identify common forms of impairment (alcohol, drugs/medications, cannabis, fatigue, distractions).
Explain legal consequences, including California Zero Tolerance rules for under‑21 and implied consent.
Apply cell phone/texting rules and safe in‑vehicle tech habits.
Recognize signs of drowsiness and choose prevention strategies.
Select safe alternatives: designated driver, rideshare, delaying a trip, and family/parental agreements.

lessons.title: How Alcohol Affects Driving
content: Alcohol is a depressant. It slows your brain’s ability to notice hazards, judge speed/distance, and react in time. Even a small amount can affect safe driving.
[object Object]
Scenario: After a Friday home game, a friend says they’re ‘fine’ after just one drink. On the quiet drive home, a ball rolls into the street. Impaired reaction time can turn this into a crash.
[object Object]

lessons.title: BAC Basics & Safe Decisions
content: Blood Alcohol Concentration (BAC) measures alcohol in your bloodstream. California sets legal limits, but any impairment can be dangerous. ‘Under the limit’ does not equal ‘safe to drive.’
[object Object]
Best move: decide your ride before the event starts. Text your parent/guardian or trusted adult the plan and a backup.
[object Object]

lessons.title: Under‑21: Zero Tolerance
content: California’s Zero Tolerance law applies to drivers under 21. If an officer suspects alcohol use, screening may be required, and even very low alcohol can trigger license actions.
[object Object]
Consequences can include vehicle impound, fines, and license suspension/delay under current California law and DMV guidance.
Bottom line: under 21 = zero alcohol while driving, and follow strict rules about transporting alcohol.

lessons.title: Implied Consent & DUI Process
content: By driving in California, you’ve agreed to chemical testing when lawfully requested (implied consent). Refusing can lead to license suspension or revocation.
[object Object]
If under 21, additional zero‑tolerance consequences can apply. Follow current CA law and the DMV handbook guidance.

lessons.title: Prescription & OTC Meds
content: Many prescription and over‑the‑counter (OTC) medications can impair alertness, vision, and reaction time. Read labels and talk to a pharmacist or doctor before driving.
[object Object]
If a label says ‘Do not operate a vehicle or machinery,’ don’t drive. Choose a safe alternative.

lessons.title: Cannabis & Combining Substances
content: Cannabis can distort time‑distance judgement, slow reaction, and reduce attention. Driving while impaired by cannabis is illegal.
[object Object]
If cannabis is present in your plans—don’t drive. Use a sober ride or wait until you are unimpaired and it is legal and safe to do so.

lessons.title: Cell Phone & Texting Rules
content: Hand‑held phone use while driving is illegal. Adults may use hands‑free only when necessary and properly mounted. Minors may not use a phone or wireless device while driving, except for emergencies.
[object Object]
Safer choice: pull over to a safe, legal location to make a call or send a message.

lessons.title: Infotainment & Other Distractions
content: Navigation, playlists, and vehicle screens can pull your eyes, hands, and mind away from driving. Set up before you shift into DRIVE.
[object Object]
Remember: ‘Eyes off the road’ for even a few seconds at speed equals a long blind travel distance.

lessons.title: Warning Signs & Circadian Dips
content: [object Object]
Circadian ‘low’ times increase risk—late night/early morning and mid‑afternoon. Don’t rely on energy drinks; they wear off.
If you feel sleepy, you’re already impaired. Stop driving.

lessons.title: Prevention Strategies
content: [object Object]
If a medication makes you sleepy, don’t drive—choose a different time or a different ride.

lessons.title: Friends, Music & Social Pressure
content: Passengers can be helpful spotters—or major distractions. As the driver, you set the tone.
[object Object]
Scenario: Your friends want a ‘story’ while you drive. You can’t film while driving. Park first or hand off the phone.

lessons.title: Food, Drinks & Loose Items
content: [object Object]
Best move: eat before or after you drive, not during.

lessons.title: Enforcement & Penalties (Overview)
content: California law provides serious consequences for DUI and under‑21 violations. Administrative license actions may occur, and courts can impose additional penalties. Requirements can include DUI education programs, proof of insurance, and ignition interlock devices in some cases.
[object Object]

lessons.title: Safer Alternatives & Family Agreements
content: Plan A/B/C: (A) designated sober driver, (B) rideshare/taxi, (C) call a parent/guardian or trusted adult. No questions asked—safety first.
[object Object]
If a friend is impaired, take the keys and choose a sober ride. Real friends protect each other.
